title: Policymakers urged to ‘stay the course' on inflation
text:
Good evening.

Fresh data from the world's two biggest economies have followed a series of warnings from policymakers gathered in Washington this week about the urgency of defeating the surge in inflation.

China today said its consumer price index edged up to 2.8 per cent in September, as easing commodity costs helped balance soaring increases in food, largely due to a jump in pork prices. Although slightly less than forecast, it was still the highest rate since April 2020 and up from August's 2.5 per cent.

Compared with the rest of the world, however, the inflation outlook in China remains relatively benign.

Data from the US yesterday showed a headline rate of 8.2 per cent in September, with the “core” CPI measure up 6.6 per cent year on year, the fastest pace in four decades, when volatile energy and food costs were stripped out. The figures initially sparked a sell-off on Wall Street as investors faced the prospect of increasingly aggressive rate rises from the Federal Reserve, but this was later reversed, with some emphasising the backwards-looking nature of CPI and that newer data showed prices falling.

Economists, however, said the bigger than expected inflation rate increase meant any hope of a “pivot” from the Fed was fading. According to the minutes of their latest meeting, the central bank's officials are more concerned about doing too little to rein in soaring US inflation than doing too much, doubling down on their plans to tighten monetary policy.

This week's meetings of the IMF and World Bank in Washington, the first in-person gatherings since the pandemic began, have been some of the bleakest since the financial crisis, writes economics editor Chris Giles.

Finance ministers and central bank governors were reminded that the world was in a “dangerous situation” and urged by the IMF to “stay the course” on fighting inflation by raising borrowing costs fast. They also shared the IMF's view that the worse was yet to come.

This course of action is not without side-effects. The rapid rise in US interest rates is causing problems across the world, driving up inflation elsewhere and fuelling market volatility.

And some countries, such as the UK, with its shambolic (and now partially reversed) “mini” Budget, were actually making things worse, the IMF argued, with inflation likely to last longer than in their peer economies. The UK was the talk of Washington, Giles reported, seen as a case study in what can happen if governments are not careful to co-ordinate fiscal with monetary policy.

Consumers, meanwhile, are being squeezed. To take just one example, UK grocery inflation hit almost 14 per cent in September, with a growing number of Britons switching to cheaper products and own-label goods.

The challenge, said IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva, was dealing with a world in transition from predictability, where rates and inflation were low, to a new era of instability. “We have to really work on changing our mindset to be much more precautionary and be prepared for much more uncertainty,” she concluded.

Need to know: the economy

UK prime minister Liz Truss summoned her chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng back from the IMF/World Bank meetings in DC and replaced him with Jeremy Hunt as the fallout from Kwarteng's “mini” Budget continued. She also ditched plans to reverse a corporation tax cut. Columnist Camilla Cavendish said the changes would not be enough to restore Britain's credibility.

Latest for the UK and Europe

Germany's deputy chancellor hit back at claims the country's €200bn energy package was selfish, arguing it will help protect the whole EU economy. The head of oil major Chevron said the west's climate policies had made energy markets “more volatile, more unpredictable, more chaotic”.

Total was accused of being complicit in Russian war crimes in Ukraine. NGOs have alleged that a Siberian gasfield part-owned by the French oil company supplied feedstock for jet fuel suspected to have been used by the Russian military against Ukrainian civilians.

Global latest

The International Energy Agency said the cut in oil output agreed by the Opec+ group could tip the world into recession. Higher crude prices would also increase energy security risks, it added. Saudi Arabia defended the cut amid fierce criticism from the US.

Emerging markets face difficult times if episodes such as the turbulence in the UK government bond market spreads and investors flee into markets such as US Treasuries, according to an IMF chief.

Xi Jinping is set to be reappointed for a third five-year term as head of the Chinese Communist party at its week-long Congress, opening on Sunday. Here's our explainer on what to expect and our Big Read on the problems posed by increasing centralisation of power in his hands.

Need to know: business

BlackRock, the world's largest money manager, reported a bigger than expected drop in assets under management in the third quarter. Profits fell at JPMorgan after the bank set aside $1.5bn for potential loan losses; by more than 30 per cent at Wells Fargo after a fake accounts scandal; and by a similar amount at Morgan Stanley following a drop-off in investment banking. Citigroup reported profits fell 25 per cent and sped up its exit from Russia.

Top US and European chip equipment suppliers have suspended sales and services for semiconductor manufacturers in China, in the first immediate fallout from sweeping new US export controls. YMTC is one of the large Chinese companies thrust into the spotlight by the move.

US investors are increasingly eyeing up British assets as the value of the pound plummets. “Everything in the UK is on sale,” said one private equity executive. Billionaire trader Chris Rokos is one of the big hedge fund managers who have profited during the crisis gripping UK financial markets. Boutique investment bank Lazard has set up a geopolitical risk unit to capitalise on global volatility.

Royal Mail threatened to cut 10,000 jobs as it revealed a first-half loss due to strike action by its workers.

The “golden quarter” — the crucial last three months of the year when UK hospitality businesses generate up to a half of their annual profits — has never looked so bleak.

Kroger agreed to buy rival Albertsons in a $24.6bn deal that could reshape the US grocery sector. Our FT Magazine cover story reports on how retail giant Walmart has managed to get longstanding antagonists such as environmentalists on its side.

Science round-up

The development of next-generation Covid-19 vaccines is being hampered by lack of funding and political will, experts have warned. The next wave is intended to offer longer-lasting or broader protection against new variants and, potentially, other coronaviruses, and be available as nasal sprays, inhalers and tablets.

There was some good news, however, from Pfizer and its German partner BioNTech, which said their new two-strain booster would provide better protection against the most common Omicron variant. They are the first to report preliminary results from a clinical trial on humans of such a “bivalent booster”.

China's decision not to allow sales of messenger RNA-based Covid-19 vaccines from Moderna or BioNTech/Pfizer is “mind boggling”, according to one of the country's most prominent biotech companies. Several Chinese pharma groups are developing mRNA alternatives but have struggled to adapt to new variants.

A nasal Covid vaccine from Oxford/AstraZeneca has failed in an early-stage trial, dealing a blow to hopes for a more effective way to prevent transmission of the virus.

GSK reported promising trial results from its potential blockbuster vaccine for respiratory syncytial virus, one of the major infectious diseases without a vaccine, despite 60 years of research.

The politicisation of attitudes to science over the past 18 months may have directly cost as many as 60,000 American lives, according to a new study from the Yale School of Public Health. Since vaccines became widely available, the deaths of registered Republicans in some states has been much higher than for Democrats.

Some good news

There is new hope for the treatment of psychiatric disease after scientists successfully implanted human brain tissue into newborn rats, where it grew neural connections that stimulated the rodents' awareness of the outside world. The work builds on more than a decade of research into human brain organoids, sometimes called “mini-brains”.
